critique: The document pertains to the appointment of John L. Lewis to the National Bituminous Coal Industrial Board in 1934, referencing the Code of Fair Competition for the Bituminous Coal Industry. This was part of the New Deal era, characterized by increased government intervention in the economy. Given this context, the document likely reflects a moderate-to-high level of government intervention in the economy. The document itself doesn't directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. Therefore, these aspects should be scored as neutral. The appointment to a board suggests a slight increase in executive power, but not significantly. The ideological tilt is moderately liberal due to the New Deal context.
